scorecard.title: Data Reporting & Quality Scorecard
scorecard.description: This scorecard assesses data reporting and quality for the state department of corrections in ${state}. Read more about our scoring methodology and to see how this jurisdiction compares to other state and federal systems.

asterisk_notes.note: The Arkansas Department of Corrections has gradually reduced the granularity of data included on its dashboard, becoming less transparent over time.
As of June 15, 2021, the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation no longer reports data about staff cases and deaths.
The Florida Department of Corrections has gradually reduced the granularity of data included on its dashboard, becoming less transparent over time.

The data we collect about COVID-19 in Massachusetts state prisons are disclosed pursuant to a court order and are published by the ACLU of Massachusetts. Because the Massachusetts Department of Correction still does not publish this data on their own website, it does not earn points for the reporting of that data.

In the past, we have observed fluctuations in the total number of COVID-19 tests and deaths reported by the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections. In January, the agency took its dashboard offline while implementing improvements and reinstated it in mid-April, after several months of limited data reporting.

Vaccination data relevant to the Michigan Department of Corrections is reported only on a statewide dashboard. While we do collect these data, the agency does not receive points because it does not make clear on its own dashboard that these data are available elsewhere.

It initially appeared that the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation & Correction reported the cumulative number of incarcerated people who have ever tested positive for COVID-19. However, we learned in April 2021 that the agency instead removes cases from its data when people are released from custody. This practice obscures the true toll of the coronavirus in Ohio prisons, and we have reduced the agency’s grade accordingly.
The Wyoming Department of Corrections has gradually reduced the granularity of data included on its dashboard, becoming less transparent over time.

releases.title: Prison and Jail Releases Related to COVID
releases.body: We collect data on jurisdictions across the U.S. that have released people from adult prison and jail custody in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

table.releases: Overall population reduction/ total # of releases

notes: For the most part, we only include release efforts where the data source includes some sort of programmatic description of who is being released (e.g., people with technical violations of parole, people charged with non-violent crimes, etc.). You can find our full prison releases dataset here and jail releases dataset here.
Date corresponds to the date of releases, if available. Otherwise, this refers to the date on which releases first were reported.
Population reduction refers to the total number of releases reported when available. Otherwise, this refers to the change in population to which the releases contributed is reported.

Population prior to releases refers to the last reported inmate population before releases were realized. Capacity is often determined differently across jurisdictions, and some facilities often report more than one capacity number. In these cases, we report the higher of the figures available.

grassroots.title: Grassroots and Community Organizing Efforts Related to COVID
grassroots.body: Our team collects data on grassroots and community organizing efforts by incarcerated people, their families, community-based organizations, nonprofits, and advocates aimed at influencing government agencies to protect the lives of people incarcerated in prisons, jails, and detention centers against the threats posed by COVID-19.
